Award.AwardTitle: STRONG COUPLING EFFECTS AND POLARITON LASING WITH GaN AND ZnO - BASED NANOWIRES

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to investigate the physics, design, fabrication and characterization of a new class of coherent light sources -- polariton lasers -- that can have ultra-low threshold powers at room temperature. The approach is to design the lasers with GaN-based nanowires grown on silicon and other substrates. Single and multiple microcavity devices with optical and electrical excitation will be characterized and analyzed.

Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit is the first comprehensive study of strong coupling and Bose-Einstein condensation in nanowires. Polariton lasing with electrical injection has not been achieved and this demonstration is transformative. Demonstration of room temperature polariton lasing and Bose-Einstein condensation are also transformative and are considered as milestones in optoelectronics. These lasers will have lower threshold powers than any other microcavity laser currently being explored.

Broader Impacts and Human Resources Development: The realization of a coherent light source which will potentially consume energy three orders of magnitude smaller than that consumed by current lasers is a quantum leap for green photonics with far-reaching consequences in telecommunication, medical and display applications. The broader impacts are the interdisciplinary nature of the research and its undergraduate and underrepresented minorities and K-12 outreach. The principal goal in education and Human Resources Development (EHRD) is to provide effective programs to educate the students involved in the research and outreach program constituents on the science and technology of photonic materials, regarded as an issue of national importance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

             This research represents the application of quantum optics and light-matter coupling to the experimental realization of electrically and optically pumped polariton coherent light-sources, the principle of operation of which is very different from that of conventional photon lasers. In this new class of laser, a coherent state of polaritons is generated by stimulated coherent polariton scattering, which is the gain mechanism. The coherent polariton state generates coherent light by spontaneous radiative recombination. Hence it is an inversionless laser with ultra-low threshold. The low threshold is extremely attractive for numerous science, biomedical and industry applications.

            The major activities of this project involved the design, materials growth, fabrication, optical and electrical characterization of GaAs, GaN and ZnO-based semiconductor/dielectric microcavities for the polariton devices under investigation. In this project, electrically injected exciton-polariton lasing has been demonstrated at both cryogenic and room temperatures for the very first time. The polariton lasing threshold of these devices, which operate in the ultra-violet and near-infrared regime of the electromagnetic spectrum, are found to be more than two orders of magnitude lower than the photon lasing threshold. Also high-speed electrical modulation has been demonstrated in an exciton-polariton laser for the first time. These outcomes open the pathway towards the development of ultra-low threshold coherent light sources for medical and biomedical applications or short distance plastic fiber communication at short wavelengths (violet and ultra-violet), where a conventional laser is difficult to realize.

            Our demonstration of the first electrically pumped polariton lasers based on both GaAs and III-Nitride material systems is a significant achievement in the field of optoelectronics and can be considered as a truly transformative result. The results and analyses presented in this work will increase the exposure of this field to the general public and other research disciplines, which will further benefit the development of this field. The research reported in this project has been conducted by graduate students, who have been trained and educated in optoelectronics, quantum optics and solid state electronics. The project has been committed to promoting learning opportunities, in the relevant areas, for women and underrepresented groups. Undergraduate students have been involved in the summer months. Some of the best experimental facilities in the world, such as clean rooms and nanofabrication facilities, have been available to students working on this project. Hence this project will provide trained professionals in the relevant areas of science and technology. Altogether, the field of quantum optics and solid-state electronics represented by this project will enhance STEM learning and advance research in science and engineering.
